resources.string: Perfect Pi is a collaboration between Stockholm Mathematics Centre(SMC) and students from the computer science faculty at KTH in order to arise interest for mathematics in general and pi especially. The project is an Open source project licensed under Apache License Version 2.0 (http://www.apache.org/license). The source code is available on https://github.com/deltagruppen/circles/.
Try to draw a circle as round as possible. An approximation of π will be computed from the drawn circle.

π is the ratio between a circles perimeter and it\'s diameter. In Perfect Pi the goal is to draw a circle with that same ratio. Begrudgingly this is impossible. To begin with π has an infinite amount of decimals so however close you get it\'s always possible to get even closer. There are also technical limitations. The display consists of pixels which form a grid. So all figures drawn are represented by patterns of horizontal and vertical lines which when zoomed out can be made to look like round shapes. But if you\'re really good and witty you can still get a value close to π.

The computations are based on the isoperimetric inequality. It says that for all circles the inequality 4πA ≤ L² is true. This means that if you multiply a closed curve\'s area (A) with 4π the result will always be less or equal to the perimeter (L) squared.
By rewriting the isoperimetric inequality we end up with a relationship that can be used to compute the π-value for a circle (I).

When a user drags his finger on the display data is collected. This data is made up of points in an array. Line segments are then created between every point which represent the drawn circle. To find a figure which can be used in the calculations the list of line segments is searched for a point where two line segments intersect or meet. The two line segments and all line segments in between form a closed curve which can be used in the calculations. If no line segments intersect or meet a new line segment is created from the first point to the last.
Getting the length of the perimeter is easily done by adding the length of all the lines together. Calculating the area is a bit more tricky if you want a good result.

Pi is an irrational number, therefore it cannot be written as a fraction and it has an infinite decimal expansion. Two well-used approximations of pi are 3,14 and 22/7.

About 250 years b.c Archimedes calculated an approximation of pi by using an algorithm that consists of engraving a circle in between two polygons. By computing the circumference he found that the value of pi was between 223/71 and 22/7. Because of this pi is also called archimedes constant.

Euler\'s identity is considered to be one the most beautiful equation in mathematics and was discovered by Leonhard Euler in 1743. It assembles the five most fundamentals numbers in mathematics: 0, 1, the unit of imaginary numbers ´i´, the base of natural logarithm ´e´ and of course pi.

The number pi has a thousand year old story. Ever since the babylonians around 2000 years b.c estimated the value of pi to 25/8, mathematicians and civilizations have struggled and attempted to get a more precise value and today we have estimations of pi with several billions decimal places.
